ORDER

This is an application filed under Section 482 of the Bharatiya Nagarik
Suraksha Sanhita, seeking pre-arrest bail.

2. The petitioner is alleged to have committed the offences punishable
under Sections 296(b), 126(2), 351(3), 118(1) and 110 of the Bharatiya Nyaya
Sanhita, and Crime No. 166/2025 of Balaramapuram Police Station is registered
against the petitioner arraying him as the accused.

Criminal M.C.No.571/2025 1/5

3. The prosecution allegation in brief is as follows:- On 04.02.2025 at
about 7.40 a.m., while the defacto complainant was driving his autorickshaw
along the Thembamuttom-Villikulam Road, and when the vehicle reached near
Karathala Temple, the accused, who was riding a scooter along the said road,
wrongfully restrained the defacto complainant, uttered abusive words against him,
and thereafter, hacked him, using a knife, on his forehead, nose and right knee,
causing injuries.

4. Notice in this bail application is issued to the Public Prosecutor. The
Investigating Officer filed report opposing the anticipatory bail application.

5. Heard. Perused the records.

6. | The only point to be considered is, whether an order of anticipatory
bail can be granted to the petitioner/ accused.

7. The Point:- The petitioner/accused was running a stationery store,
and the defacto complainant was a regular customer in that store. It is alleged that,
in view of some dispute between the two, in relation to the accounts maintained in
the stationery store regarding the purchase of provisions made by the defacto
complainant, the petitioner/accused had assaulted the defacto complainant, using a
knife.

8. According to the petitioner, he is absolutely innocent of the

Criminal M.C.No.571/2025 2/5

allegations levelled against him and he has been falsely implicated in this case. It
is submitted that, the petitioner is conducting a stationery store business, and the
defacto complainant, who is a regular customer in his shop, used to purchase
stationary items, on credit basis, and while so, on 03.02.2025, the defacto
complainant misbehaved with the lady staff of the shop and abused her and when
the petitioner questioned the same, on 04.02.2025, the defacto complainant, under
the influence of alcohol, chased and attacked the petitioner while he was returning
home, and he sustained injuries in the said incident and he took treatment from
Family Health Centre, Balaramapuram.

9. There is serious allegation as against the petitioner. Going by the
First Information Statement given by the defacto complainant, it is seen that, the
defacto complainant had purchased some stationery goods from the shop of the
accused and some amount was due from the defacto complainant, and later, he had
paid some amount, and there was a dispute between the two in not entering the
same, and thereafter, due to that animosity, the petitioner had attacked the defacto
complainant while the defacto complainant was going in his autorickshaw. In the
body note appended to the First Information Statement, it is stated that, the wound
of the defacto complainant over his forehead, nose and right leg were seen
dressed. The case of the petitioner is that, when the petitioner questioned the

Criminal M.C.No.571/2025 3/5

misbehavior of the defacto complainant with the lady staff of his shop, the defacto
complainant had, in fact, attacked the petitioner, and that the petitioner sustained
injuries, and he was treated at Family Health Centre, Balaramapuram. Along with
the bail application, he had produced a prescription slip from Family Health
Centre, Balaramapuram. Apparently, there is some dispute between the two in
view of the purchase of stationery from the shop of the petitioner. In view of the
disparity between the two, an exaggeration of the case cannot be ruled out. No
material is produced by the prosecution, apart from the First Information Report,
to show that, the allegation against the petitioner carries some weight. It would be
a travesty of justice, if the petitioner is put behind the bars, if actually he has not
committed the offence. No criminal antecedents of the petitioner is brought to the
notice of this court.

10. In view of my discussion above, it appears that there is no
impediment in granting a pre-arrest bail to the petitioner. Considering all these
aspects, it is found that this is a fit case where a pre-arrest bail can be granted to
the petitioner.

In the result, the petition is allowed

the petitioner.

In the result, the petition is allowed on the following conditions:-
(1) In the event of arrest, the petitioner/ accused shall be released
on bail on his executing bond for Rs.50,000/- (Rupees Fifty
Thousand only) with two solvent sureties for the like sum
Criminal M.C.No.571/2025 4/5

each to the satisfaction of the arresting officer/Investigating

Officer, as the case may be.

(2) Petitioner shall appear before the Investigating Officer

between 10 a.m. and 11 am. on every Wednesday for a

period of 3 (three) months or till the filing of the final report,

whichever is earlier.

(3) Petitioner shall also appear before the Investigating Officer as
and when required.

(4) Petitioner shall not commit any offence while on bail.

(5) Petitioner shall not attempt to contact the defacto complainant

or any of the prosecution witnesses, directly or through any

other person, or in any other way try to tamper with the

evidence or influence any witnesses or other persons related

to the investigation.

In case of any violation of the above conditions or misuse of liberty,
the prosecution or the defacto complainant is at liberty to approach jurisdictional
court for cancellation of bail.

(Dictated to the Confidential Assistant, transcribed and typed by him, corrected and

pronounced by me in Open Court on this the 28" day of February 2025)
Sd/-
